origin: Auto insurance companies use credit scores to discriminate against low-income Michiganders. @RashidaTlaib wants that to change. https://bit.ly/2UHf6vD¬†
replies:
Insurance companies have mountains of data showing the correlation between credit score and insurance claims -- auto and homeowners.  

So offering lower rates to those with good credit scores makes sense.

And it's a reward to those of us who work to keep our credit scores good.

"work to keep your credit score good" = Being lucky enough to never get laid off from a job or have an unexpected medical expense. It's just discrimination against poverty at the end of the day, and no, poor people who are lucky enough to have high scores don't negate that.
I‚Äôve been both unexpectedly laid off AND have had major unplanned medical medical expenses, with little to no savings, and my credit score is above 750 so cut the crap.
Oh yes, your singular anecdote is evidence that the entire system works for everyone and no one on earth has a different experience from you.

Also, big surprise someone who is an investment trader is shilling for the credit reporting industry.  Lemme guess, you had a 4 or 5 digit "little to no savings" account when you were laid off and health insurance for your "unexpected medical expense"?

I got fired, got in a motorcycle accident & spent 23 days in the hospital.

I am ECSTATIC if I ever see a ‚Äúcomma‚Äù in my bank account ON PAY DAY. Yet, I have a 770+ credit score... Don‚Äôt live outside your means! Make a budget! Live by it. Save for those days you get laid off.
